DNVGL-RU-SHIP Pt.4 Ch.8 Electrical installations
Changes – current
This document supersedes the July 2021 edition of DNV-RU-SHIP Pt.4 Ch.8.
Changes July 2022, entering into force 1 January 2023
Topic Reference Description
Section 1 is rearranged Sec.1 [1] Aligned Sec.1 with standard DNV structure, including presentation of all documentation requirements and requirements for compliance documents.
Sec.1 [1.6.2], previous Sec.13 Deleted previous Sec.13. Moved to Sec.1.
Sec.2 [2.1.1] Moved guidance note from previous Sec.13.
Sec.10 [1.1.4], previous Sec.13 Moved short circuit proof installation from previous Sec.13.
Sec.11 [3.1.2], previous Sec.13 Moved marking of certified safe equipment from previous Sec.13.
Alignment with DNV-OS-D201 Sec.1 Table 7 Added that system philosophy is generally required, but may be exempted upon request.
Sec.2 [1.2.4] Changed exemption for voltage deviations.
Sec.10 [3.5.4]
Deleted word 'normally', added guidance note about accepting smaller cable bending radius.
Sec.10 [4.4.13] Added reference to IEC.
Sec.11 [3.2.4]
Sec.11 [3.3.4]
Re-written text to clarify intention.
High fire risk areas and fire resistant cables Sec.2 [9.5.2] Described high fire risk areas in accordance with IACS SC 11.
Sec.2 [10.1.2] Updated in line with IACS UR E15.
Section 1 Service description
1 General
1.1 Objective
The objectives of this chapter are to:
  • define technical requirements and guidance for design, manufacturing, and installation of electrical installations on ships
  • specify procedures and requirements for electrical installations on ships subject to DNV classification.
1.2 Scope
The section covers the following systems and arrangements, including relevant equipment:
  • electric power supply systems
  • battery systems
  • electric power distribution
  • switchgear and controlgear assemblies
  • rotating machines
  • electrical equipment and cables
  • hazardous area installations
  • electric propulsion
  • installation.
1.3 Application
  1. The rules in this chapter apply to electrical installations for assignment of main class. The requirements in this chapter dealing with safety for personnel, fire and explosion hazards do apply to all types of electrical installations that are installed on board. The technical requirement to equipment applies even if DNV product certificate or DNV type approval certificate is not required.
  2. The requirements dealing with availability of electrical power supply apply to electrical installations serving essential or important services, see Table 4.
  3. For installations of less than 100 kVA total main generator capacity, the Society may apply modified rules for both technical requirements and for the verification process. Modified requirements shall be agreed upon in each case and shall be made available for the operational phase.
  4. Portable electric appliances are not applicable to classification.
1.4 Supplementary requirements
1.4.1 Other relevant class rules
  1. For certain electrical installations, other parts of the rules apply. Examples are:
    • The additional class notation Battery applies to battery installations in battery powered vessels as required by Pt.6 Ch.2 Sec.1. The qualifier Safety applies to vessels with large lithium-ion batteries installed, superseded by qualifier Power where batteries are used as propulsion power.
    • The additional class notation FC is mandatory to all vessels with fuel cell power installations on board as required by Pt.6 Ch.2 Sec.3. The qualifier Safety is mandatory for all vessels with fuel cell power installations not used in essential, important or emergency services. This qualifier is replaced with the qualifier Power which is mandatory for all vessels with fuel cell power installations intended for use in essential, important or emergency services.
    • The additional class notation Shore power applies to vessels utilizing electrical shore connections while in port and is mandatory for vessels with HV shore connection and LV shore connection with a power ratings greater than or equal to 1 MVA as required by Pt.6 Ch.7 Sec.5. This is applicable for shore power supplying the distribution grid onboard the vessel.
  2. Supplementary requirements will be enforced for vessels according to its ship type and additional class notations, as required by the respective parts of the rules.
1.4.2 IEC standards
  1. The requirements in this chapter are generally based on applicable standards for ships as issued by IEC (the International Electrotechnical Commission).
  2. Where direct reference is made to such standards, it is meant the standard(s) in force at the time of contract between builder and owner.
This implies primarily the IEC 60092 series for ships.
1.4.3 Other standards
  1. The Society will consider the use of alternative standards if they are found to represent an overall safety concept equivalent to that of the rules.
  2. Acceptance of the use of other standards may be given without builder’s or owner's or operator’s consent. An application for acceptance of other standards shall be submitted. Upon request, a copy of an English version of the standard shall be submitted.
Special care should be taken when requirements from different standards are used within the same system.
1.5 References
Table 1 lists DNV references used in this document.

1.6 Definitions and abbreviations
1.6.1 Definition of verbal forms
The verbal forms defined in Table 3 are used in this document.
Table 3 Definition of verbal forms
Term Definition
shall verbal form used to indicate requirements strictly to be followed in order to conform to the document
should verbal form used to indicate that among several possibilities one is recommended as particularly suitable, without mentioning or excluding others
may verbal form used to indicate a course of action permissible within the limits of the document
1.6.2 Definition of terms
The terms defined in Table 4 are used in this document.
Table 4 Definition of terms
Term Definition
battery systems
interconnection of electrical batteries wired in series, parallel or as a combination of both connections
Battery management system, if installed, is considered as a part of the battery system.
blackout situation
situation when there is a sudden loss of electric power in the main distribution system and remains until the main source of power feeds the system
All means of starting by stored energy are available.
cable
assembly consisting of:
  • one or more cores
  • assembly protection
  • individual covering(s) (if any)
  • common braiding (if any)
  • protective covering(s) (if any)
  • inner and/or outer sheath
Additional un-insulated conductors may be included in the cable.
A cable may be either class 2 or class 5 as defined in IEC 60228. In a class 2 cable the conductor is made up by a minimum number of strands. In a class 5 cable the conductor is made up by many small strands with a maximum size according to IEC 60288.
certified safe equipment
equipment certified by an independent national test institution or competent body to be in accordance with a recognised standard for electrical apparatus in hazardous areas
conductor
part of a construction or circuit designed for transmission of electric current
continuity of service
condition for protective system and discrimination, after a fault in a circuit has been cleared, the supply to the healthy circuits is re-established
continuity of supply
condition for protective system and discrimination, during and after a fault in a circuit, the supply to the healthy circuits is permanently ensured
controlgear
general term covering switching devices and their combination with associated control, measuring, protective and regulating equipment, also assemblies of such devices and equipment with associated interconnections, accessories, enclosures and supporting structures, intended in principle for the control of electric energy consuming equipment
(See IEC 60050-441-11-03)
core
assembly consisting of a conductor and its own insulation used as part of a cable
dead ship condition
condition under which the entire machinery installation, including the power supply, is out of operation and that auxiliary services such as compressed air, starting current from batteries etc., for bringing the main propulsion into operation and for the restoration of the main power supply are not available
For a more detailed definition of dead ship, see Ch.1 Sec.3.
deck and bridge zone
area (EMC zone) in close proximity to receiving and/or transmitting antennas and the wheelhouse as well as the control rooms, characterized by equipment for intercommunication, signal processing, radio communication and navigation, auxiliary equipment and large openings in the metallic structure
(See EMC zone definition in IEC 60533)
distribution board (DB)
any switchboard utilised for distribution to electrical consumers, but which is not considered as a main switchboard
electrical assembly (assembly of switchgear and controlgear)
combination of switchgear and/or controlgear completely assembled with all internal electrical and mechanical interconnections
(See IEC 60050-441-12-01)
electrical installations
all-inclusive general expression that is not limited to the physical installations
For physical installations, the wording 'installation of …' is used.
EMC zone
area characterized by sensitive and/or disturbing devices located therein
emergency condition
condition under which any services needed for normal operational and habitable conditions are not in working order due to the failure of the main electrical power system
emergency distribution board (EDB)
any switchboard utilised for distribution to electrical emergency consumers, but which is not considered as an emergency switchboard
emergency electric power supply system
emergency source of electrical power and associated electrical distribution including:
  • emergency generators
  • batteries
  • associated transforming equipment, if any
  • the transitional source(s) of emergency power, if any
  • the emergency switchboards (ESB)
  • emergency distribution boards (EDB)
  • all cables from the emergency generator to the final consumer
  • control systems and auxiliary systems needed to be in operation for the mentioned systems or equipment
emergency services
services that are essential for safety in an emergency condition and equipment required to be powered from the emergency source of power
Examples of equipment and systems for emergency services:
  • equipment and systems that need to be in operation in order to maintain, at least, those services that are required to be supplied from the emergency source of electrical power
  • equipment and systems that need to be in operation in order to maintain, at least, those services that are required to be supplied from the accumulator battery for the transitional source(s) of emergency electrical power
  • equipment and systems for starting and control of emergency generating sets
  • equipment and systems for starting and control of prime movers (e.g. diesel engines) for emergency fire fighting pumps
  • equipment and systems that need to be in operation for the purpose of starting up manually, from a dead ship condition, the prime mover of the main source of electrical power (e.g. the emergency compressor)
  • equipment and systems that need to be in operation for the purpose of fire fighting in the machinery spaces. This includes emergency fire fighting pumps with their prime mover and systems, when required according to DNV-OS-D301
  • equipment required to be powered from the emergency source of power, as e.g.:
    • navigational lights and signals
    • navigation equipment
    • internal and external safety communication equipment.
emergency source of electrical power
power source intended to supply the emergency switchboard and/or equipment for emergency services in the event of failure of the supply from the main source of electrical power
Emergency source of electrical power may be generator(s) or battery(ies).
A generator prime mover and associated equipment is called emergency generators' primary source of power.
emergency switchboard
switchboard, which in the event of failure of the main electrical power supply system, is directly supplied by the emergency source of electrical power and/or the transitional source of emergency power and is intended to distribute electrical energy to the emergency power consumers
Switchboards not being directly supplied by the emergency source of power may be considered as emergency switchboards when this is found relevant from a system and operational point of view.
Normally all switchboards between the emergency source of electrical power and (inclusive) the first level of switchboards, for power distribution to small power consumers, should considered to be emergency switchboards (ESBs) (i.e. at least one level of switchboards for each voltage level used).
essential services (primary essential services)
services required to be in continuous operation to maintain the vessels’s manoeuvrability in regard to propulsion and steering
(See IACS UI SC134)
The definition may also apply to other services when these are defined as such in the relevant rule chapter.
Examples of equipment and/or systems for essential services:
  • control, monitoring, and safety devices or systems for equipment for essential services
  • scavenging air blower, fuel oil supply pumps, fuel valve cooling pumps, lubricating oil pumps, and freshwater cooling water pumps for main and auxiliary engines
  • viscosity control equipment for heavy fuel oil
  • ventilation necessary to maintain propulsion
  • forced draught fans, feed water pumps, water circulating pumps, condensate pumps, oil burning installations, for steam plants on steam turbine vessels, and also for auxiliary boilers on vessels where steam is used for equipment supplying primary essential services
  • steering gears
  • azimuth thrusters which are the sole means for propulsion or steering, with lubricating oil pumps and cooling water pumps
  • electrical equipment for electric propulsion plant, with lubricating oil pumps and cooling water pumps
  • pumps or motors for controllable pitch propulsion or steering propellers, including azimuth control
  • hydraulic pumps supplying the above equipment
  • electric generators and associated power sources supplying the above equipment.
general power distribution zone
area (EMC zone) characterized by normal consumers
(See EMC zone definitions in IEC 60533)
hazardous area
area (zones and spaces) containing a source of hazard and or in which explosive gas and air mixture exists, or may normally be expected to be present in quantities such as to require special precautions for the construction and use of electrical equipment and machinery
high resistance earthed neutral
system earthing where the neutral is earthed through a resistance with numerical value equal to, or somewhat less than, 1/3 of the capacitive reactance between one phase and earth
high voltage
rated voltages of more than 1 kV and up to and inclusive 15 kV with rated frequencies of 50 Hz or 60 Hz, or direct-current systems with the maximum voltage under rated operating conditions above 1 500 V
ingress protection
protection of enclosures in regard to intrusion of particles and water, and against accidental touching of live parts
(See IEC 60529)
Table 5 Ingress protection of enclosures
First characteristic numeral Protection against intrusion of particles and against accidental touching of live parts
0
Non-protected
1
Protected against solid objects greater than 50 mm
2
Protected against solid objects greater than 12.5 mm
3
Protected against solid objects greater than 2.5 mm
4
Protected against solid objects greater than 1.0 mm
5
Dust protected
6
Dust tight
Second characteristic numeral
Protection against intrusion of water
0
Non-protected
1
Protected against dripping water
2
Protected against dripping water when tilted up to 15º
3
Protected against spraying water from above up to 60º from vertical
4
Protected against splashing water
5
Protected against water jets
6
Protected against heavy seas
7
Protected against the effects of immersion
8
Protected against submersion (water depth to be given)
Additional letter A, B, C, or D may be added to indicate degrees of protection against access to hazardous part. Further, supplementary letters (e.g., H, M, S or W) may be added to provide information about compliance with additional requirements in relevant product standard.
(See IEC 60529)
important services (secondary essential services)
services that are not required to be in continuous operation to maintain the vessel's manoeuvrability, but which are necessary for maintaining the vessels functions as defined in Pt.1 Ch.1 Sec.1 [1.2], or other relevant parts of the rules
(See IACS UI SC134)
Important electrical consumers are electrical consumers serving important services.
Electrical equipment necessary to fulfil requirements to additional class or service notations shall be considered important equipment, when this is given by the relevant rules.
Examples of equipment or systems for important services covered by main class:
  • anchoring system
  • thrusters not part of steering or propulsion
  • fuel oil transfer pumps and fuel oil treatment equipment
  • lubrication oil transfer pumps and lubrication oil treatment equipment
  • pre-heaters for heavy fuel oil
  • seawater pumps
  • starting air and control air compressors
  • bilge, ballast and heeling pumps
  • ventilating fans for engine and boiler rooms
  • ventilating fans for gas dangerous spaces and for gas safe spaces in the cargo area on tankers
  • inert gas fans
  • fire and gas detection and alarm system
  • main lighting system
  • electrical equipment for watertight closing appliances
  • electric generators and associated power sources supplying the above equipment
  • hydraulic pumps supplying the above equipment
  • control, monitoring and safety systems for cargo containment systems
  • control, monitoring and safety devices or systems for equipment to important services
  • jacking motors
  • water ingress detection and alarm system
  • auxiliary boilers in vessels with HFO as the main fuel.
low resistance earthed neutral
system earthing where the neutral is earthed through a resistance which limits the earth fault current to a value of minimum 20% and maximum 100% of the rated full load current of the largest generator
low voltage
rated voltages of more than 50 V up to and inclusive 1 000 V with rated frequencies of 50 Hz or 60 Hz, or direct-current systems where the maximum voltage does not exceed 1 500 V
main electric power supply system
main source of electric power and associated electrical distribution including:
  • main source of electrical power
  • batteries
  • associated transforming equipment, if any
  • the main switchboards (MSB)
  • distribution boards (DB)
  • all cables from generators to the final consumer
  • control systems and auxiliary systems needed to be in operation for the mentioned systems or equipment
main generating station
space in which the main source of electrical power is situated
main source of electrical power
power source intended to supply electrical power to the main switchboard(s) for distribution to all services necessary for maintaining the vessel in normal operational and habitable conditions
A generator prime mover and associated equipment is called generators' primary source of power.
main switchboard
switchboard directly supplied by the main source of electrical power or power transformer and intended to distribute electrical energy to the vessel’s services
Switchboards not being directly supplied by the main source of power will be considered as main switchboards when this is found relevant from a system and operational point of view.
  1. Normally, all switchboards between the main source of electrical power and (inclusive) the first level of switchboards for power distribution, to small power consumers, should considered to be main switchboard (MSBs) (i.e. at least first level of switchboards for each voltage level used).
  2. Cubicles for other system voltages attached to a main switchboard should be considered part of the main switchboard.
manned control station
location normally manned so that any alarms are readily noticed by an operator
The term is used in a wider meaning than the SOLAS definition of the term control station and includes an engine control room ECR (if any).
neutral conductor
conductor connected to the neutral point of a system, and capable of contributing to the transmission of electric energy
non-important services
services not defined as essential or important, or those services that are not required during blackout recovery, dead ship recovery, emergency condition, or for maintaining normal operational and habitable condition
normal operational and habitable condition
condition under which the vessel, as a whole, is in working order and functioning normally
off-line UPS unit
UPS unit where under normal operation the output load is powered from the input power supply (via bypass) and only transferred to the inverter if the input power supply fails or goes outside preset limits
This transition will invariably result in a brief break in the load supply.
on-line UPS unit
UPS unit where under normal operation the output load is powered from the inverter, and will therefore continue to operate without break in the event of the power supply input failing or going outside preset limits
open deck
deck that is completely exposed to the weather from above or from at least one side
permanent magnet machine
machine where the main air-gap flux is created by permanent magnets
A synchronous machine with an auxiliary excitation machine with permanent magnets is not considered to be a permanent magnet machine.
safety voltage
rated voltage not exceeding 50 V AC or DC
sealed battery
battery of the type in which cells are hermetically sealed and a safety vent, or venting mechanism, exists for abuse conditions
Lead acid batteries are not sealed batteries.
semi-conductor assembly
combination of semiconductor converters, switchgear and/or controlgear completely assembled with all internal electrical and mechanical interconnections
semi-conductor converter
device converting incoming electric power to electric power of another frequency
This covers:
  • rectifier, a device converting alternate power to direct power
  • inverter, a device converting direct power to alternate power
  • frequency converter, a device converting alternate power to alternate power of another frequency, where the output frequency may be controllably varied.
short circuit proof installation
installation method used for low voltage installations to limit the risk of short circuit
special power distribution zone
area (EMC zone) characterized by propulsion systems, bow thrusters, etc. producing emissions exceeding the limits given for the general power distribution zone
(See EMC zone definitions in IEC 60533)
switchgear
general term covering switching devices and their combination with associated control, measuring, protective and regulating equipment, also assemblies of such devices and equipment with associated interconnections, accessories, enclosures and supporting structures, intended in principle for use in connection with generation, transmission, distribution and conversion of electric energy
(See IEC 60050-441-11-02)
switchgear and controlgear
general term covering switching devices and their combination with associated control, measuring, protective and regulating equipment, also assemblies of such devices and equipment with associated interconnections, accessories, enclosures and supporting structures
(See IEC 60050-441-11-01)
Electric equipment intended to be connected to an electric circuit for the purpose of carrying out one or more of the following functions: protection, control, isolation, switching.
(See IEC 60050-826-16-03)
tracking index
numerical value of the proof voltage, in volts, at which a material withstands 50 drops without tracking, in accordance with IEC 60112
This is a voltage value describing the isolating materials surface property to withstand tracking when wet. Determination of the tracking index is normally done by type testing of the material by the manufacturer, before the material is available in the market.
uninterruptible power system (UPS)
combination of converter, inverter, switches and energy storage means, for example batteries, constituting a power supply system for maintaining continuity of load power in case of input power failure
(See IEC 62040)
valve-regulated battery
battery of the type in which the cells are closed, but have an arrangement (valve) that allows the escape of gas if the internal pressure exceeds a predetermined value
vented battery
battery of the type where individual cells have covers, which are provided with an opening, through which products of electrolysis and evaporation are allowed to escape freely from the cells to atmosphere
wire
assembly consisting of one core and its own insulation
For definitions of terms related to switchgear and controlgear, see IEC 60947-1 for low voltage, and IEC 60470 and IEC 60056 for high voltage equipment.
1.6.3 Abbreviations
The abbreviations described in Table 6 are used in this document.
Table 6 Abbreviations
Abbreviation
Description
AC
alternating current
ACB
air circuit breaker
AVR
automatic voltage regulator
DB
distribution switchboard
DC
direct current
EDB
emergency distribution board
EMC

EN

EPR
ethylene propylene rubber
ESB
emergency switchboard
ESD
emergency shutdown
ETD
temperature measurement by the embedded temperature detector method
GIS
gas-insulated switchgear
HV

IEC
International Electrotechnical Commission
IMO
International Maritime Organisation
IP

IR

IS

MCB

MCT

MSB

NC

NEC

NEMA

P

R

SCR

T

TT

UPS

XLPE
cross-linked polyethylene
1.7 Procedural requirements
1.7.1 Work processes
  1. As a basis for assignment of class, the Society will verify that the electrical installation complies with the relevant rule requirements. This verification process is organised as follows:
    • approval of system design
    • equipment certification
    • onboard survey.
  2. The verification process is carried out on a spot check basis. The full responsibility for compliance with the applicable rules lies with the builder or any other contractually bound party.
  3. The verification process includes requirements to approval of:
    • systems (including distribution systems)
    • equipment
    • components.
    For standard designs the case-by-case approval may be replaced by the type approval scheme.
1.7.2 Documentation requirements
1.7.2.1 General
General requirements for documentation can be found in DNV-CG-0550 Sec.6. See DNV-CG-0550 Sec.5 for definition of the documentation types.
1.7.2.2 Documentation for system design
Documentation related to system design shall be submitted as required by Table 7. Additional documentation will be required if deemed necessary.
Additional requirements for compliance documentation may be given by other relevant parts of the rules.
Table 7 System design, documentation requirements 
Object
Object
Additional description
Info
Electric power system, general
E010 - Overall single line diagram
AP
E050 - Single line diagrams/ consumer list for switchboards
For:
  • AC power systems
  • DC battery systems
  • UPS systems.
AP
E040 - Electrical load balance
For:
  • AC power systems
  • DC battery systems
  • UPS systems.
AP
E220 - Electrical system philosophy
Description of power system arrangement, operation modes, special functions, interlocks and limitations of the power system, as relevant.
If physical separation is required, location of equipment and cable routing philosophy shall be included.
May be exempted upon request if the overall single line diagram is found sufficient to give necessary understanding of the operation and relevant operation modes of the system.
FI
E200 - Short circuit calculations
Calculation of single phase fault against earth shall be included for systems with earthed neutral.
FI
E080 - Discrimination analysis
The document shall cover, as relevant:
  • generator protection
  • main switchboard circuits (Table 4)
  • emergency switchboard circuits (Table 4)
  • battery and UPS systems
  • downstream discrimination between different voltage levels under all operating conditions.
AP
Z071 - Failure mode and effect analysis
Upon request for special systems where E220 is not considered as sufficient.
R
Electric installations
Z253 - Test procedure for quay and sea trial
AP, L
Main electric power - motor starters
E170 - Electrical schematic drawing
Starters for essential services.
AP
Emergency stop system
E170 - Electrical schematic drawing
Emergency stop of electrical propulsion motors, pumps and fans, showing fail to safe functionality.
AP
Explosion (EX) protection
E090 - Table of Ex-installation
Based on approved area classification drawing and ESD philosophy (if relevant).
AP
Emergency lights
Z030 - Arrangement plan
Emergency lighting arrangement.
AP
Cable transit seal systems register
Z270 - Record
A cable transit seal systems register (register)shall be provided by the builder for all watertight cable transits fitted to the vessel. See IACS UR Z28.
FI, L
AP = for approval, FI = for information, R = on request, L = local handling.
1.7.2.3 Onboard documentation
During onboard survey, the following documentation shall be available for the Society’s surveyor:
  • approved design documentation and documentation submitted for information as required by Table 7
  • DNV compliance documents for equipment as required
  • approved area classification drawing and ESD philosophy where relevant
  • applicable Ex certificates
  • manufacturer’s declaration for non-certified equipment that is installed in a hazardous area
  • additional documentation where deemed necessary to assess the installations' compliance with the rules
  • cable routing arrangement.
1.7.2.4 Documentation for component certification
Electrical equipment required to be delivered with DNV product certificate, see Table 9, shall be documented as described in Table 8. For equipment covered by a valid DNV type approval certificate, this certificate may specify exceptions to document approval. Additional documentation will be required if deemed necessary.
Table 8 Component certification, documentation requirements 
Object Documentation type Additional description Info
Cable
E110 - Cable data sheet and design drawing
For cables not having a DNV type approval certificate (TAC).
AP
Electric propulsion motors and generators in mechanical propulsion line
C030 - Detailed drawing
Shafting for electric propulsion motors and generators in mechanical propulsion line, as required by Ch.4.
AP
Permanent magnet electric rotating machines
C070 - Permanent magnet machine documentation
AP
Main- and emergency switchboards
E120 - Electrical data sheet, general
FI
E140 - Assembly schedules and technical data

When designed sub-transient short circuit strength exceeds 50 kA r.m.s.

E160 - Internal arc withstanding report
High voltage assemblies only.

When software based control units are used.

For high voltage switchgear and control gear.

For high voltage switchgear and control gear.

Applicable for propulsion control system integrated in main propulsion drives for diesel electric or hybrid propulsion and drives for aux thrusters on DP vessels.
Also applicable for control systems in converters for battery power/safety notations.
AP
Control system for remote and/or automatic control of power system
I200 – Control and monitoring system documentation
AP
Electrical components being certified based on alternative test methods (i.e. generators, motors, transformers, converters
Z252 - Test procedure at manufacturer
Procedure for testing of electrical equipment describing the selected method for testing, measurement and calculations used for verification in accordance with the rules requirements.
AP
AP = for approval, FI = for information.
1.7.2.5 Equipment covered by a valid DNV type approval certificate is accepted without design assessment, unless otherwise stated in the certificate. A copy of the type approval certificate will substitute the required documentation for DNV design assessment. A product certificate may be issued based on the DNV type approval certificate and a product survey, unless otherwise stated in the DNV type approval certificate.
1.7.2.6  For manufacturers having type approved cables, only routine tests according to Sec.9 will be required in order to obtain a product certificate for a specific cable of similar design as covered by a type approval.
Type test reports may be requested for important components not having a valid DNV type approval certificate.
Type approved products have been verified to be suitable for the marine environment.
1.7.3 Required compliance documentation
All electrical equipment serving essential, important or emergency services and sources of main or emergency power shall be delivered with DNV product certificate (PC) and/or DNV type approval certificate (TAC) as required by Table 9.
Table 9 Compliance documents
Object
Compliance document type 2)
Compliance standard 1)
Continuous rating
Additional description
Main and emergency switchboard
PC
All
Electrical assemblies (distribution switchboards, motor starters, motor control centres, starting transformers. braking resistors, etc.) 6), 9)
PC
≥ 100 kW/kVA
The electrical assemblies shall be certified based on requirements given in the applicable rule section.
Electric slip ring units
PC
≥ 100 kW/kVA
Electric slip ring units shall be delivered with a product certificate in any of the following cases:
  1. The slip ring unit transfers power to essential or important consumers, and total transferred power to is more than 100 kW.
  2. The slip ring unit is used for essential control/automation systems.
  3. In cases falling under a): any additional slip rings for instrumentation or control/automation shall be part of the certification..
See Sec.8.
For hydraulic and/or pneumatic systems, please see requirements to certification given in relevant rules as e.g. Ch.6.
Harmonic filters installed to reduce level of THD
PC
> 50 kVA
Intended for filter units. Not filters incorporated in the certification of frequency converters. Relevant requirements are found in Sec.4 and Sec.7.
Standardized switchgear units manufactured in series with smaller clearance distances than given in Sec.4 Table 1
TAC
≥ 100 kW/kVA
See Sec.4 [1.1.8].
Generators 4) and transformers
PC
≥ 300 kVA
Generators 4) and transformers
TAC
≥ 100 kVA and < 300 kVA
Electric motors 4)

≥ 300 kW

TAC
> 100 kW and < 300 kW

> 100 kW
Certification of semi-conductor converters for motor drives may partly be based on type approval of power modules.
Semi-conductor converters/assemblies for
power supply 5)

> 50 kVA
Certification of semi-conductor converters for power supply may partly be based on type approval of power modules.
Cables 3), 7)
TAC

For termination of aluminium cables.
Sealing compound and packing systems for bulkhead- and deck penetrations

For penetrations in fire rated
or watertight bulkheads.
Busbar trunking systems
TAC

Control and monitoring system - remote and/or automatic control of power system
PC
When the system includes protective functions, these functions shall be type approved in accordance with Ch.9. TAC is mandatory prior to issuing a PC.
Computer based lighting controllers
TAC
  1. Unless otherwise specified the compliance standard is the DNV rules.
  2. Equipment not having valid type approval certificate may be accepted on the basis of a DNV product certificate.
  3. All cables, except:
    1. cables for internal use in electrical assemblies
    2. short cable lengths on mechanical packages
    3. communication cables for non-important equipment
    4. radio frequency coaxial cables.
  4. Certificates for shafts shall be issued as required by Ch.4.
    This is only applicable for shafts part of the main mechanical propulsion line.
  5. Ancillaries such as pumps, electric motors, coolers, piping, filters, valves, etc. that are delivered as integral parts of equipment, need not to be delivered with separate product certificates, but shall be checked as found relevant by the attending surveyor.
  6. For assemblies with integrated components like transformers or motors, the components shall be certified additionally based on test requirements given in the applicable rule section. E.g. starting transformers shall additionally be certified based on the tests required in Sec.6 when continuous rating exceeds 100 kVA.
  7. Lightweight cables and aluminium cables are only accepted based on a DNV type approval certificate.
  8. Termination accessories for aluminium cables (cable lugs, crimping tools, etc.) shall be type approved. This type approval requires that termination accessories are tested together with the aluminium cable.
  9. For product certification of switchgear with a smaller clearance distances than given in Sec.4 Table 1 shall be based on the manufacturer's type test report as required by Sec.4 [1.1.8].
For general compliance documentation requirements, see DNV-CG-0550 Sec.4.
For a definition of the compliance document types, see DNV-CG-0550 Sec.3.
1.7.4 Survey requirements
1.7.4.1 Onboard survey
  1. Onboard survey shall be performed as part of the classification process, and focuses on the installation on board as well as on the functionality of the electrical system.
  2. Onboard inspections shall be performed in order to evaluate that:
    • the electrical installation is in accordance with the accepted or approved information
    • the electrical installation is in accordance with the requirements in the rules
    • the craftsmanship is acceptable.
  3. Function tests shall be performed as part of the Society’s verification of the installation’s compliance with the requirements in the rules and approved documentation.
1.7.4.2 Product survey
  1. A product survey is performed as part of the certification process. The survey includes:
    • review of the manufacturers documentation
    • documentation of results from type tests shall, if performed, be available
    • visual inspection
    • testing.
  2. Visual inspection shall verify that:
    • manufacturing and installation is in accordance with the approved design information as required by Table 8
    • the product manufacturing is in accordance with the requirements in the relevant equipment section of the rules
    • general craftsmanship is acceptable.
  3. The extent of the manufacturer’s testing shall be as required by applicable sections of the rules. The testing shall be performed in accordance with approved test programme(s) when required by Table 8. Test results shall be recorded and filed.
Section 2 System design
1 General
1.1 Design principles
1.1.1 General requirements
  1. Electrical power supply systems onboard fall into different categories:
    • main electric power supply system
    • emergency electric power supply system
    • transitional electric power supply system
    • single consumers with a dedicated battery for support in a blackout (e.g. radio station or fire alarm central).
  2. The main electric power supply system shall be a redundant system, functionally independent of any other power supply system onboard. The requirements to this system are given in [2].
  3. The emergency electric power supply system is not required to be a redundant system. It shall function independently of the main electric distribution system. The requirements to this system are given in [3].
  4. The transitional electric power supply system is seen as an addition to the emergency power supply system. The requirements to this system are given in [3].
  5. Dedicated battery support to single consumers may be regarded as parts of the emergency power supply system, dependent on the function of the supported equipment.
  6. All consumers that support functions required to be available in normal operation shall be supplied from distribution systems independent of the emergency electrical power supply system. Exemptions are made for consumers for which mandatory requirements permit emergency power only and for one of redundant consumers necessary for dead ship recovery.
  7. All consumers required to be available in emergency operation shall be supplied from distribution systems independent of the main electric power supply system.
  8. Consumers required having both main and emergency supply shall be supplied as required by relevant rules applicable for these consumers. The primary supply shall be from the main system.
  9. Vessels without a dedicated emergency electric power supply system are accepted upon compliance with requirements in [3.1.4].
Requirements to arrangements of main and emergency power supply systems with respect to fire, flooding or other casualty are given in [9.1.3].
1.1.2 Environmental conditions
The electrical installations shall be suitable for operation in a marine environment. Detailed requirements are given in Sec.3 [2], and have an ingress protection rating as given in Sec.10 [2.2]. For the requirements for ventilation and air conditioning, see [9.1.1]. For electrical equipment installed within environmentally controlled spaces, see [9.1.2].
1.1.3 System earthing
  1. System earthing shall be effected by means independent of any earthing arrangements of the non-current-carrying parts.
  2. Any earthing impedances shall be connected to the hull. The connection to the hull shall be so arranged that any circulating current in the earth connections do not interfere with radio, radar, communication and control equipment circuits. (IACS UR E11 2.1.4)
  3. If the system neutral is connected to earth, suitable disconnecting links or terminals shall be fitted so that the system earthing may be disconnected for maintenance or insulation resistance measurement. Such means shall be for manual operation only.
  4. Earthed distribution systems shall only have a single connection between the neutral point and earth. If generator neutrals are connected to earth at several points, equalising currents in the neutral earthing exceeding 20% of the rated current of connected generators or transformers are not acceptable. Transformer neutrals and generator neutrals shall not be simultaneously earthed in the same distribution system at same voltage level. On distribution transformers with star connected primary side, the neutral point shall not be earthed.
  5. In any four wire distribution system the system neutral shall be connected to earth at all times when any consumer is connected.
  6. Combined PE (protective earth) and N (system earth) is allowed between transformer/generator and N-busbar in first switchboard where the transformer secondary side/generator is terminated i.e. TN-C-S-system. There shall be no connection between the N–conductor and the PE-conductor after the PEN-conductor is separated.
  7. In case of earth fault in high voltage systems with earthed neutral, the current shall not be greater than full load current of the largest generator on the switchboard or relevant switchboard section and not less than three times the minimum current required to operate any earth fault protection relay.
  8. Electrical equipment in directly earthed neutral or other neutral earthed systems shall withstand the current due to single phase fault against earth for the time necessary to trip the protection device.
  9. It shall be assured that at least one source neutral to ground connection is effective whenever the system is in the energised mode. For divided systems, connection of the neutral to the earth shall be provided for each section.
    (IACS UR E11 2.1.5 and 2.1.2)
  10. For earthing of aluminium superstructures on steel vessels see [9.7].
1.1.4 Types of distribution systems
  1. AC power: The following distribution systems can be used (for exemptions see [1.1.5]):
    • three-phase three-wire with high-resistance earthed neutral
    • three-phase three-wire with low-resistance earthed neutral
    • three-phase three-wire with directly earthed neutral
    • three-phase three-wire with insulated neutral.
  2. In addition for all voltages up to and including 500 V AC:
    • three-phase four-wire with neutral earthed, but without hull return
    • single-phase two-wire with insulated neutral
    • single-phase two-wire with one phase earthed at the power source, but without hull return.
  3. DC power: The following distribution systems can be used (for exemptions see [1.1.5]):
    • two-wire insulated
    • two-wire with one pole earthed at the power source (without hull return)
    • single-wire with hull return as accepted in [1.1.5].
1.1.5 Hull return systems
  1. The hull return system of distribution shall not be used, except as stated in b) and c). (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/45.3.1)
  2. Provided that any possible resulting current does not flow directly through any gas hazardous spaces, the requirements of a) does not preclude the use of:
    • impressed current cathodic protective systems
    • limited and locally earthed systems
    • insulation level monitoring devices provided the circulation current does not exceed 30 mA under the most unfavourable conditions
    • intrinsically safe circuits.
    (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/45.3.2)
  3. Where the hull return system is used for distribution of DC power, one of the busbars of the distribution board shall be connected to the hull. Outgoing final sub circuits i.e. all circuits fitted after the last protective device shall be with insulated two-wires or two-core cables. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/45.3.3)
1.1.6 Special requirements for non-metallic craft
  1. All metal parts of a non-metallic craft shall be bonded together, in so far as possible in consideration of galvanic corrosion between dissimilar metals, to form a continuous electrical system, suitable for the earth return of electrical equipment and to connect the craft to the water when water-born. The bonding of isolated components inside the structure is not generally necessary, except in fuel tanks.
  2. Each pressure refuelling point shall be provided with a means of bonding the fuelling equipment to the craft.
  3. Metallic pipes capable of generating electrostatic discharges, due to the flow of liquids and gases shall be bonded so they are electrically continuous throughout their length and shall be adequately earthed.
  4. Secondary conductors provided for the equalisation of static discharges, bonding of equipment, etc., but not for carrying lightning discharges shall have a minimum cross section of 5 mm2 copper or equivalent surge current carrying capacity in aluminium.
  5. The electrical resistance between bonded objects and the basic structure shall not exceed 0.02 Ohm except where it can be demonstrated that a higher resistance will not cause a hazard. The bonding path shall have sufficient cross-sectional area to carry the maximum current likely to be imposed on it without excessive voltage drop.
  6. A main earth bar shall be defined and fitted at a convenient place on board. This earth bar shall be connected to a copper plate with a minimum area of 0.25 m2 attached to the hull and so located that it is immersed under all conditions of heel.
1.2 System voltages and frequency
1.2.1 General
  1. Electric distribution systems shall operate within the voltage and frequencies given in [1.2.1] to [1.2.7]. This also applies to distribution systems where one or more generator prime movers are driving other equipment. When the main propulsion engine is used as a generator prime mover, variations caused by the wave motion or sudden manoeuvres including crash stop, shall not exceed the given limitations.
  2. Voltage variations deviating from the standard values are accepted in systems if these are intentionally designed for the actual variations.
  3. All voltages mentioned are root mean square values unless otherwise stated.
The standardised voltages and frequencies are intended for distribution systems where 'over the shelf' equipment shall be connected.
Where deviating voltages or frequencies are used, all connected equipment shall be designed for the selected distribution both with respect to voltages and frequencies as well as the tolerances that should be expected.
1.2.2 Maximum system voltages
  1. Except as stated in b) and c), the following maximum voltages in distribution systems apply:
    • connected by permanent wiring: 17 500 V
    • for portable appliances, which are not hand-held during operation, and with connection by flexible cable and socket outlet: 1 000 V
    • supply for lighting (including signal lamps), space heaters in accommodation spaces, and hand-held portable appliances: 250 V. Phase voltage of a system with neutral earthed may be used for this purpose.
  2. For high speed, light craft and naval surface craft, the maximum distribution voltage is limited to 500 V, except for crafts with electric propulsion systems, where higher voltages are accepted.
  3. Where necessary for special application, higher voltages may be accepted by the Society.
    (IACS UR E11 1.2)
1.2.3 Maximum control voltages
For control equipment being a part of power and heating installations (e.g. pressure or temperature switches for start and stop of motors), the maximum voltage is 1000 V. However, control voltage to external equipment shall not exceed 500 V.
1.2.4 Supply voltage variations
  1. Electric AC distribution systems shall be designed and installed so that the voltage variations on main switchboards are maintained within these limits:
    • Steady state
    ±2.5% of nominal AC system voltage for main power distribution.
    ±3.5% of nominal AC system voltage for emergency power distribution.
    • Transient state
    from −15% to +20% of nominal AC voltage.
  2. Electric DC battery powered systems shall be designed and installed so that the voltage variations on the main distribution board are maintained within these limits:
    • Voltage tolerance:
      • +30% to -25% for equipment connected to battery during charging
      • +20% to -25% for equipment connected to battery not being charged
      • voltage cyclic variation: max 5%
      • voltage ripple: max 10%.
  3. The requirement for maximum transient voltage shall also be complied with in case of load shedding or tripping of consumers. The requirement for maximum transient undervoltage is not applicable to failure conditions.
  4. After a transient condition has been initiated, the voltage in a main distribution AC system shall not differ from nominal system voltage by more than ±3% within 1.5 s. In an emergency distribution system the voltage shall not differ from nominal system voltage by more than ±4% within 5 s.
  5. In AC installations designed for variable system voltage, equipment and its protection devices shall be rated to operate within the design limits throughout the voltage range.
For total load rejection/generator disconnection see Sec.5 [2.2.3].
1.2.5 Voltage variations in the distribution system
  1. An AC distribution system shall be designed and installed so that the stationary voltage drop in supply to individual consumers, measured from the main switchboard to the consumer terminals does not exceed 6% of system nominal voltage.
  2. A DC distribution system shall be designed and installed so that the stationary voltage variation in supply to individual consumers, measured from the battery distribution to the consumer terminals, does not exceed ±10% of system nominal voltage. Voltage ripple and cyclic variation deviation as stated in [1.2.4].
  3. Specific requirements for transient voltages on consumer terminals during start or stop are not given. However, the system shall be designed so that all consumers function satisfactorily.
1.2.6 System frequency
  1. The frequency variations in AC installations with fixed nominal frequency shall be kept within the following limits:
    • 95 to 105% of rated frequency under steady load conditions
    • 90 to 110% of rated frequency under transient load conditions.
  2. In AC installations designed for variable system frequency, equipment and its protection devices shall be rated to operate within the design limits throughout the frequency range.
See Ch.2 Sec.5 regarding the prime movers' speed governor characteristics.
1.2.7 Harmonic distortion
  1. Equipment producing transient voltage, frequency and current variations shall not cause malfunction of other equipment on board, neither by conduction, induction or radiation.
  2. In distribution systems the acceptance limits for voltage harmonic distortion shall correspond to IEC 61000-2-4 Class 2. In addition, no single order harmonic shall exceed 5%.
    IEC 61000-2-4 Class 2 implies that the total voltage harmonic distortion shall not exceed 8%.
  3. The total harmonic distortion may exceed the values given in b) under the condition that all consumers and distribution equipment subjected to the increased distortion level have been designed to withstand the actual levels. The system and components ability to withstand the actual levels shall be documented.
  4. When filters are used for limitation of harmonic distortion, special precautions shall be taken so that load shedding or tripping of consumers, or phase back of converters, do not cause transient voltages in the system in excess of the requirements in [1.2.4].
The following effects should be considered when designing for higher harmonic distortion, refer to c):
  • additional heat losses in machines, transformers, coils of switchgear and controlgear
  • additional heat losses in capacitors for example in compensated fluorescent lighting
  • resonance effects in the network
  • functioning of instruments and control systems subjected to the distortion
  • distortion of the accuracy of measuring instruments and protective gear (relays)
  • interference of electronic equipment of all kinds, for example regulators, communication and control systems, position-finding systems, radar and navigation systems.
A declaration or guarantee from system responsible may be an acceptable level of documentation.
1.2.8 Passive and active harmonic filter assemblies/units
  1. Where the electrical distribution system on board a ship includes harmonic filter units, the system integrator of the distribution system shall show, by calculation, the effect of a failure of a harmonic filter unit on the level of harmonic distortion experienced. The system integrator of the distribution system shall provide the ship owner with guidance documenting permitted modes of operation of the electrical distribution system while maintaining harmonic distortion levels within acceptable limits. The system integrator shall also calculate the harmonic distortion that will be experienced in case of a failure of a harmonic filter, and provide guidance on mitigating actions in form of operating modes or reduced power levels.
  2. Where the electrical distribution system on board a ship includes harmonic filter units, the levels of harmonic distortion experienced on the main busbar shall be continuously monitored. Should the level of harmonic distortion exceed the acceptable limits, an alarm shall be given at a manned location. For ships with class notation E0, the alarm shall be logged.
  3. Harmonic filters integrated in frequency converters, or installed for single consumers such as e.g. pump motors may be excluded from these requirements.
See IACS UR E24.
2 Main electric power supply system
2.1 General
2.1.1 Capacity
  1. The main electric power supply system shall have the capacity to supply power to all services necessary for maintaining the ship in normal operational and habitable conditions without recourse to an emergency source of power. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/40.1.1). Exemptions are made for consumers for which mandatory requirements permit emergency power only and for one of redundant consumers necessary for dead ship recovery.
  2. Except as given in c), there shall be component redundancy for main sources of power, transformers and power converters in the main power supply system so that with any source, transformer or power converter out of operation, the power supply system shall be capable of supplying power to the following services:
    • those services necessary to provide normal operational conditions for propulsion and safety
    • starting the largest essential or important electric motor on board, except auxiliary thrusters, without the transient voltage and frequency variations exceeding the limits specified in [1.2]
    • ensuring minimum comfortable conditions of habitability which shall include at least adequate services for cooking, heating, domestic refrigeration (except refrigerators for air conditioning), mechanical ventilation, sanitary and fresh water
    • for a duplicated essential or important auxiliary, one being supplied non-electrically and the other electrically (e.g. lubricating oil pump no. 1 driven by the main engine, no. 2 by electric motor), it is not expected that the electrically driven auxiliary is used when one generator is out of service
    • for dead ship recovery, see [2.2.5].
    (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch. II-1/41.1)
  3. Reduced or modified requirements to redundancy and/or capacity of the main power supply system may be accepted for vessels not required to follow requirements given in SOLAS. For vessels where other IMO instruments or where national regulations apply, or for vessels having service restrictions, requirements given in these instruments or regulations may be applied. The basis for acceptance will be included in the appendix to the classification certificate.
For normal operational and habitable condition, the following services should be operational, as relevant:
  • propulsion machinery
  • steering gear
  • safe navigation
  • fire and flooding safety
  • internal and external communications and signals
  • means of escape
  • emergency lifeboat winches
  • anchor winches
  • lighting necessary to perform normal operation and maintenance of the vessel
  • designed comfortable conditions for habitability, including cooking, heating, domestic refrigeration, mechanical ventilation, sanitary and fresh water
  • utility systems for the listed functions.
Exemptions are made for consumers for which IMO requires emergency power only. Such consumers are considered as emergency consumers, and not as required for normal operational and habitable conditions.
Those services necessary to provide normal operational conditions of propulsion and safety do not normally include services such as:
  • thrusters not forming part of the main propulsion or steering
  • mooring
  • cargo handling gear
  • refrigerators for air conditioning
  • ballast water treatment system
  • exhaust gas cleaning systems for the reduction of NOx and SOx.
However, additional class notations may add services to the list of important services.
In regard to non-important load, the capacity of all generators can be taken into consideration.
2.1.2 Sources of main electric power
  1. A source of main electric power may be a mechanically driven generator, or static devices like fuel cells, photovoltaic cells or batteries. Each source of main electric power shall be a separate, independent unit, and shall not depend on any common components (e.g. common gearbox).
  2. If a prime mover for a generator is also used for driving other auxiliary machinery in such a way that it is physically possible to overload the prime mover, an interlock or other effective means for preventing such overloading shall be arranged.
  3. A generator or generator system, having the ship's main propulsion machinery as its prime mover, may be accepted as a main source of electrical power, provided that it can be used in all weather conditions and operating modes for the vessel, including standstill of the vessel. The main propulsion machinery shall comply with [2.2] with respect to starting capability in a blackout situation.
  4. Shaft generators and generators based on variable speed drives will be evaluated in each case. As a minimum, the following should be evaluated:
    • availability in all operating modes
    • stability of output voltage and frequency
    • short circuit capability and protection
    • auxiliary systems, e.g. ventilation, cooling system, and control power distribution.
    If a source of main electrical power is a rotating generator driven by a generator driver, the requirements in Ch.2 Sec.5 applies.
2.2 System functionality
2.2.1  Redundancy types for main power
General requirements to redundancy are given in Ch.1 Sec.3 [2.3]. With respect to failures in the main power system, the principles shall be understood as explained in Table 1:
Table 1 Redundancy types for main power distribution system
Redundancy type
With respect to failure in
Comment
R1
an electric consumer or a main source of power
When main electric power supply system is necessary for propulsion or steering.
R2
an electric consumer or a main source of power
When main electric power supply system is not necessary for propulsion or steering.
R2
an electric busbar assembly, distribution transformer or power distribution converter
For SOLAS compliant vessels and HSC compliant vessels where main electric power supply system is necessary for propulsion of the vessel.
Note: Bus tie shall provide discrimination in high voltage systems and in some DC distribution systems, as given in [7.1.4] f) and h).
R3
an electric busbar assembly, distribution transformer or power distribution converter
For vessels where main busbar divisions are not required by IMO codes or statutory requirements.
See Ch.1 Sec.3 [2.3] for general principles to redundancy types of machinery systems.
For requirements to division of main busbars, see [6.1.3] and [6.1.4].
When permanent magnet shaft generator(s) is used, see guidance note to Ch.1 Sec.3 [2.3.7] for redundancy types for propulsion.
2.2.2 Start of main sources of power
  1. At least two sources of main power, connected to separate main busbar sections, shall be arranged with systems for starting in a blackout situation.
  2. For vessels where a) is not complied with, e.g. where the main electric power supply system relies on a dedicated source of main power for restoration in a blackout situation, the design may be accepted on a case by case evaluation given that:
    • The dedicated source of power may not be the only source in operation in any allowed operating mode.
    • In case the dedicated standby source fails, it shall be possible to start another main source of power. The emergency source of power may be utilised for this starting provided the capacity cover both normal emergency consumption simultaneously with required number of starting attempts for the main source of power.
    • Since the design is seen as imposing operating restrictions to the electrical system onboard, limitations shall be described in the 'Electric system philosophy' required in Sec.1 Table 7.
    • Necessary information for planning of safe operations of the vessel shall be included in the appendix to the classification certificate.
    • Testing in order to demonstrate the systems capabilities to start in a blackout situation shall be included in the system tests required by Sec.10 [4.4].
2.2.3 Energy for starting
  1. The stored energy used for starting and connecting a source of power in a blackout situation shall be arranged as required in [5.1].
  2. It shall be possible to start and connect sufficient power sources to supply the consumers required by [2.2.2] without recourse to energy sources located outside of the machinery space where the main source of power is installed.
  3. Control power supply to electronic governors, automatic voltage regulators (AVRs) and necessary control power for auxiliary systems shall, if dependent on external power, be arranged as required for starting arrangement in [5.1.2].
  4. Where prime movers and/or sources of power arranged as standby sources depend upon auxiliary machinery systems being available in a blackout situation, these auxiliaries shall be arranged as required for starting arrangements in [5.1.2]. At least one of the sources of power shall be from stored energy located within the engine room. The capacity of the power sources shall correspond to the required number of starting attempts and/or last for at least 30 minutes.
  5. Where prime movers and/or generators arranged as standby generators depend upon auxiliary machinery systems during standby mode in order to start in a blackout situation, auxiliaries for at least one generator shall be supplied from the main switchboard in order to comply with [1.1.1].
Example of auxiliary system that must be available in a blackout situation may be fuel oil booster pump, and lubrication oil pump if start blocking is activated within 30 minutes after blackout.
Example of auxiliary system that must be supplied in standby mode may be pre lubrication pump and jacket water heating.
2.2.4 Load shedding and automatic restoration of power
Where electrical power is necessary for propulsion and steering of the ship, the system shall be so arranged that the electrical supply to equipment necessary for propulsion and steering, and to ensure safety of the vessel, will be maintained or immediately restored in case of loss of any one of the sources of power in service.
This means:
  • The power system shall be equipped with automatic load shedding or other automatic means to prevent sustained overload of any source of power, see [7.1.1].
  • Upon loss of power, provision shall be made for automatic starting and connecting to the main switchboard of standby source(s) of sufficient capacity, and automatic restarting of the essential auxiliaries, in sequential operation if required. Starting and connection to the main switchboard of the standby source of power shall be preferably within 30 s, but in any case not more than 45 s, after loss of power. Either restart of the previous running auxiliary, or start of a standby auxiliary system is accepted.
  • Where prime movers with longer starting time are used, this starting and connection time may be exceeded upon approval from the Society.
  • Where several power units in parallel operation are required to cover the ship's power supply, the failure of one of the units shall cause the immediate trip of non-important equipment and, where necessary, the important equipment, where this is the only way to ensure that the remaining units can be kept in operation to permit propulsion and steering and to ensure safety. Load reduction may be one solution to achieve this.
(Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/41.5.1.1)
Automatic starting and connecting to the main switchboard of standby source(s) will not be functional if the circuit breaker is locked out due to activation of it's short circuit protection.
2.2.5 Start from dead ship
  1. The main electric power supply system shall be such as to ensure that with any one source of main power, transformer or power converter out of service, the remaining sources of power, transformers and power converters shall be capable of providing the electrical services necessary to start the main propulsion plant from a dead ship condition. The emergency source of electrical power may be used for the purpose of starting from a dead ship condition if its capability either alone or combined with that of any other source of electrical power is sufficient to provide at the same time those services required to be supplied by [3.1.2] or [3.1.3], except fire pumps and steering gear, if any.
  2. Capability to start the propulsion plant from a dead ship condition may not be required for non-convention vessels. For vessels where other IMO instruments, or where national regulations apply, or for vessels having service restrictions, requirements given in these instruments or regulations may be applied. The basis for acceptance shall be included in the appendix to the classification certificate.
The general requirement for start from dead ship is given in Ch.1.
On installations without a dedicated emergency generator in accordance with [3.1.4], only one of the engine room is considered to be in dead ship conditions simultaneously since there should be redundancy in starting arrangement for each engine room as required for emergency generator sets. However, necessary energy for auxiliaries needed for start (fuel, lubrication oil priming, etc.) shall have the same arrangement as the source for starting energy.
For vessels with two or more independent engine rooms but not complying with [3.1.4], both/all engine rooms are considered to be in dead ship condition simultaneously, and the requirements given in a) applies.
In cases where only electric starting is arranged for engines driving generators and the main propulsion engines, an additional battery for dead ship starting may be installed. This battery shall then be dedicated for this purpose and always kept fully charged and monitored.
Temporary back-feeding of emergency power to the main distribution system may be utilised in order to provide power for dead ship starting.
2.2.6 Regeneration
Regenerated power caused by e.g. water milling of propellers shall not cause any alarms, neither in planned operating modes nor during emergency manoeuvres. Where necessary, braking resistors for absorbing or limiting such energy shall be provided.
3 Emergency electric power supply system
3.1 General
3.1.1 Emergency source of power
  1. A self-contained emergency source of electrical power shall be provided.
  2. The emergency source of power shall have sufficient capacity to supply all services essential for safety in an emergency, due regard being paid to such services as may have to be operated simultaneously, also taking into account starting currents and transitory nature of certain loads. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/43.2).
  3. The emergency source of power shall be automatically connected to the emergency switchboard in case of failure of the main source of electric power, and within 45 s supply at least the services required to be supplied by transitional power as listed in Table 2. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/43.3.1.2, 43.3.2.2 and 43.3.2.3).
  4. The emergency source of power shall be capable of being readily started under all temperature conditions likely to occur.
  5. Where the emergency source of electrical power is an accumulator battery, it shall be capable of carrying the emergency electrical load without recharging while maintaining the voltage of the battery as required by [1.2]. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/43.3.2.1)
  6. When non-emergency consumers are supplied by the emergency source of power, it shall either be possible to supply all consumers simultaneously, or automatic disconnection of non-emergency consumers upon start of the generator shall be arranged. The system shall be so arranged that the largest consumer connected to the emergency power supply system can be started at all times without overloading the generator unless automatically disconnected upon start of the emergency generator. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/43.5.5)
  7. Starting air compressors, pre-heaters and lubrication oil pumps for the main engine or auxiliary engines may be equipped for automatic disconnection from the emergency switchboard. Such consumers necessary for starting from dead ship, if supplied from the emergency source of power, shall be possible to connect manually at the emergency switchboard also when the emergency generator is running. If they may cause overloading of the emergency generator, warning signs shall be fitted also stating the load of the consumers.
  8. The emergency switchboard shall be situated as near as possible to the emergency source of power.
  9. The emergency electric power system shall be located above the uppermost continuous deck and be readily accessible from the open deck.
  10. The space containing the emergency electric power system shall not be contiguous to the boundaries of machinery spaces of category A or those spaces containing the main source of electrical power.
  11. Ventilation of the space containing the emergency source of electrical power shall comply with the requirements in Ch.1 Sec.3 [1.1.7].
  12. Cooling fans and/or pumps arrangement for the emergency source of power, shall be located in the same space as the emergency generator. Radiators with fans may be accepted outside, in close vicinity to the emergency source of power.
  13. The emergency source of power shall not be used for supplying power during normal operation of the vessel. Exceptionally, and for short periods, the emergency source of power may be used to supply non-emergency circuits, for starting from dead ship, or short term parallel operation with the main source of electrical power for the purpose of load transfer and for routine testing of the emergency source of power.
    (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/42.1.4 and 43.1.4).
The wording 'emergency electric power system' used in this paragraph shall be read as: 'emergency source of power and the main parts of the emergency power distribution system, including any transformers, converters, transitional source of power and the emergency switchboard of any distribution system voltage level'.
The wording 'main source of electrical power' used in this paragraph shall be read as: 'main source of electrical power and the associated distribution system, up to, and including, main switchboards at any system voltage level'.
3.1.2 Additional requirements to SOLAS vessels
  1. For cargo vessels that shall comply with SOLAS requirements, the following requirements apply:
    • The emergency electric power system shall not be located forward of the collision bulkhead.
    • The emergency electric power system shall be located so that a fire or other casualty in spaces containing the main source of electrical power or in any machinery space of category A will not interfere with the supply, control and distribution of the emergency electric power system.
  2. For ships that shall comply with SOLAS requirements to cargo vessels, the list of services in Table 2 shall be supplied by an emergency source of power and by a transitional source of power, if required, for the period listed.
  3. For a ship engaged regularly in voyages of short duration, a period shorter than the 18 hours period specified in Table 2 may be accepted. (Interpretation of SOLAS Ch.II-1/43.2.6.2)
Table 2 Services to be supplied by an emergency source and by a transitional source, including required duration for vessels that shall comply with SOLAS requirements to cargo ships

See SOLAS Ch.IV/13

  • the MF radio installation required by SOLAS Ch. IV/9.1.1, Ch.IV/9.1.2, Ch.IV/10.1.2 and Ch.IV/10.1.3
  • the ship earth station required by regulation SOLAS Ch.IV/10.1.1
  • the MF/HF radio installation required by regulations SOLAS Ch.IV/10.2.1, Ch.IV/10.2.2, Ch.IV/10.1.2 and Ch.IV/11.1.
18
See SOLAS Ch.IV/13
All internal communication equipment, as required, in an emergency, shall include:
  • means of communication between the navigating bridge and the steering gear compartment
  • means of communication between the navigating bridge and the position in the machinery space or control room from which the engines are normally controlled
  • means of communication between the bridge and the positions fitted with facilities for operation of radio equipment.

For ships seeking compliance with NAUT(OSV), see Pt.6 Ch.3.
18 1)
Alarm systems 5)
The fire detection and alarm systems.
18 1)
0.5 2)

18 1)
7)
The gas detection and alarm systems.
18 1)
0.5 2)
The general alarm system.
18 1)
0.5 2)
  1. Unless such services have an independent supply for the period of 18 hours from an accumulator battery suitably located for use in an emergency.
  2. Unless such equipment has an automatically charged battery with adequate capacity, suitably located for use in an emergency.
  3. Means of communication according to relevant SOLAS requirements and DNV statutory interpretations apply for mandatory internal communications systems.
  4. A transitional source of power is required for:
    • vessels where the emergency source of power is not automatically connected to the emergency switchboard within 45 seconds
    • class notations Passenger ship, Ferry and SPS.
  5. Only when the service or function is required by other applicable rules.
  6. Power for launching of the life boat shall be available on demand with duration of 10 minutes for each lifeboat.
  7. The alarm sounder system utilised by the fixed fire detection and fire alarm system shall be powered from no less than two sources of power, one of which shall be an emergency source of power. In vessels required by SOLAS Ch.II-1/42 or 43 to be provided with a transitional source of emergency electrical power the alarm sounder system shall also be supplied from this power source. (IACS UI SC35)
  8. Personnel lifts need separate certificates issued by a competent authority recognised by the flag state. It is listed here as a capacity requirement to the emergency source of power.
3.1.3 Modified requirements to non-SOLAS vessels
  1. For vessels that are not required to be compliant with the SOLAS regulations, and where no other IMO codes, national regulations, or class notations specify particular requirements, there shall be a self-contained emergency source of electrical power located above the bulkhead deck, in a readily accessible place which shall not be contiguous to machinery spaces of category A or those spaces containing the main source of electric power or main switchboard.
  2. For vessels where the main source of electrical power is located in two or more rooms which are not adjacent, the requirement for a self-contained emergency source of electrical power is considered satisfied when:
    • an emergency source of electrical power is installed above the bulkhead deck which at least has the capacity of supplying, for a period of at least three hours, the following consumers:
      • emergency lighting:
        • at every muster or embarkation station and over the sides
        • in all alleyways, stairways and exits giving access to the muster or embarkation stations
      • the ship's navigation lights
    • each of the rooms has its own complete system for the production of electrical power, including power distribution and control systems, which are completely independent of each other
    • fire or other casualty in any of the rooms will not affect the power distribution from the others or the services required in c).
  3. The emergency source of power shall be capable of operating:
    • for a period of at least half an hour, power operated watertight doors together with the associated control, indication and alarms
    • for a period of at least three hours, simultaneous operation of the following services (when such a service is required by other regulations):
      • emergency lighting:
        • at every muster or embarkation station and over the sides
        • in all alleyways, stairways and exits giving access to the muster or embarkation stations
        • in the machinery spaces, and in the place where the emergency generator is situated
        • in the control stations where radio and main navigating equipment is situated
        • at the emergency bilge pump and one of the fire pumps, and at the starting position of their motors
